doc.after: Built by William Pool for RanavalonaÂ II, Fiangonana ("Chapel") required eleven years to complete.[16] The structure's foundation stone was laid onÂ 20 July 1869,[61] and its subsequent construction used over 35,000Â hand-chiselled stones.[37] Inaugurated on 8Â April 1880,[35] the central worship space measured 12.9 metres (42Â ft) wide and 18.5 metres (61Â ft) in length with an estimated capacity of 450 persons. The building was designed with a private pew for the royal family, elevated on a platform approximately 0.91 metres (3.0Â ft) high and accessed by a short staircase. A private entrance available to the royal family was accessible by a decorative exterior bridge linking the chapel to the raised embankment upon which Manampisoa stood.[61]
